review_body: Dark Passion Play\" ist für mich das beste Nightwish-Album überhaupt und hat seit seinem Erscheinen meinen CD-Player kaum noch verlassen. Die Band hat bewiesen, dass sie sich nicht über die Stimme sondern über ihre außergewöhnliche Musik definiert, die in der gesamten Musikszene absolut konkurrenzlos ist.   Anette hat Frische und Power in die Band gebracht und hat mich vollkommen überzeugt (ein Vergleich mit Tarja erübrigt sich schon auf Grund der komplett unterschiedlichen Gesangstechnik).     Gerade was die Musik anbelangt, finde ich, dass sich Nightwish absolut treu geblieben sind.   Insbesondere beeindruckt war ich von der \"Vielschichtigkeit\" dieses Albums: damit meine ich den gewohnten metal-symphonischen Nightwish-Sound kombiniert mit den irish-folkigen Elementen in \"The Islander\" und \"Last of the Wilds\", die orientalischen Klänge in \"Sahara\" und \"Whoever brings the Night\", die Bombast-Hymne \"7 Days to the Wolfes\", dazu die sanften \"Eva\" und \"Meadows of Heaven\", das fast schon brutale \"Master Passion Greed\", das frische \"Amaranth\", das aggressive \"Bye bye Beautiful\" und, last but not least, der geniale Ớpener \"The Poet and the Pendulum\", der direkt unter die Haut geht.    Besser gehts nicht! Für mich ist einfach kein Schwachpunkt erkennbar. Nightwish pur - nur eben mit veränderter, aber sehr ausdrucksstarker und gefühlvoller Stimme.     Die 5 Sterne hat sich das Album mehr als verdient ;-)

The band has proven that they did not define themselves on the voice but about their extraordinary music that runs throughout Music scene is absolutely unrivaled. Anette has brought fresh and power into the band and has completely convinced me (a comparison with Tarja is already unnecessary due to the completely different vocal technique). Just what the music is concerned, I find that Nightwish has remained absolutely faithful are. In particular, I was from the "complexity" of this album: so I mean the usual metal-symphonic Nightwish sound combined with the Irish-femarkig elements in \ "The Islander \" and \ "Last of the Wilds \" , the oriental sounds in "Sahara" and \ "Whoeover Brings The Night \", the Bombast-Hymne \ "7 Days to the Wolfes \", to the gentle \ "Eva \" and \ "Meadows of Heaven \" , D AS almost brutal \ "Master Passion Greed \", the fresh \ "Amaranth \", the aggressive \ "Bye bye Beautiful \" and, last but not least, the ingenious ớpenter \ "The Poet and the Pendulum \", the right under the skin goes. Better is not! For me, just no weakness is recognizable. Nightwish pure - just with changed, but very expressive and soulful voice. The 5 stars has more than deserves the album ;-)

review_body: Dr. Sayer (Robin Williams) ist ein Forscher, wie man ihn sich so vorstellt. Allein und von seinen Büchern umgeben wohnt er in einem Reihenhaus und bestimmt Pflanzen nach dicken Botanik-Fibeln. Kürzlich bewies er, dass man eine bestimmte Substanz nicht aus Regenwürmern gewinnen kann. Er ist menschenscheu, aber freundlich und zuvorkommend. Leider kann er von seinem Hobby nicht leben. Deshalb bemüht er sich um eine Anstellung in einer neurologischen Klinik. Da dort Not am Mann ist und Sayer früher einmal Medizin studiert hat, nimmt man ihn. Viel falsch machen kann man in dieser Klinik nicht. Dort werden hoffnungslose Fälle verwaltet. Aber so neurotisch Sayer auch ist, sein Forscherdrang und seine kindliche Hilflosigkeit machen ihn liebenswürdig. Zufällig entdeckt er, dass eine regungslos vor sich hin vegetierende Patientin dennoch erstaunliche Reflexe besitzt.  Nun erwacht die Neugier in ihm. Er findet schnell heraus, dass andere Insassen mit dem gleichen Krankheitsbild über dieselben Fähigkeiten verfügen. Mehr noch: Sie haben auch eine ähnliche Verlaufsgeschichte.  Als er dann noch von einer neuen synthetischen Droge erfährt, die ihm geeignet erscheint, das noch vorhandene innere Leben der Betroffenen nach außen zu tragen, erreicht er, dass er sie seinem Lieblingspatienten Leonard (Robert de Niro) verabreichen kann. Das Wunder geschieht tatsächlich und die Begeisterung ist groß. Doch wie so oft in der Medizin ist der Mechanismus der scheinbaren Heilung weitgehend unklar. Nach einiger Zeit verfallen zunächst Leonard und danach auch die anderen Betroffenen wieder in ihren alten Zustand zurück. Sie erleben also nicht nur zum zweiten Mal ihren geistigen und körperlichen Verfall, sondern in der Phase der scheinbaren Heilung auch den Schmerz, dass sie ihr Leben eigentlich verpasst haben. Dieses Drama wird uns an Leonard in seiner ganzen Traurigkeit vor Augen geführt.  Dieser auf einer wahren Geschichte beruhende Film lebt nicht nur von den sehr emotionalen Augenblicken des Erwachens und dem hoffnungsvollen, aber kurzem Wachsein dieser armen Menschen, sondern auch von seiner klaren Botschaft: Manchmal ist das Leben kurz, gehen wir also achtsam mit ihm um.  Das Duo Williams und de Niro machen aus der ohnehin schon sehr emotionalen Geschichte durch ihr brillantes Spiel einen einfühlsamen Film, der in Erinnerung bleiben wird.emotionalen Augenblicken des Erwachens und dem hoffnungsvollen, aber kurzem Wachsein dieser armen Menschen, sondern auch von seiner klaren Botschaft: Manchmal ist das Leben kurz, gehen wir also achtsam mit ihm um.     Das Duo Williams und de Niro machen aus der ohnehin schon sehr emotionalen Geschichte durch ihr brillantes Spiel einen einfühlsamen Film, der in Erinnerung bleiben wird.

Alone and surrounded by his books, he lives in a terraced house and determines plants according to thick botany fibulae. Recently he proved that one can not gain a certain substance from earthworms. He is human shy, but friendly and accommodating. Unfortunately, he can not live from his hobby. Therefore, he strives for a job in a neurological clinic. Since there is not the man and Sayer once studied medicine once, it takes him. Make a lot wrong in this clinic. There are hopeless cases are managed. But so neurotic Sayer too is, his research harness and his childish helplessness make him amiable. Coincidentally, he discoveres that a motionless patient, a motionless patient has stunning reflexes. Now the curiosity awakens in him. He quickly finds out that other occupants have the same clinical image over the same skills. More: You also have a similar history. When he learns from a new synthetic drug that seems appropriate to carry the still existing inner life of those affected outwards, he achieves that he can administer them of his favorite patient Leonard (Robert de Niro). The miracle actually happens and the enthusiasm is great. But as so often in medicine, the mechanism of apparent healing is largely unclear. After some time, Leonard continues to expire and then the other concerned back in their old state. So, for the second time you will experience your spiritual and physical decay, but in the phase of apparent healing also the pain that you have actually missed your life. This drama is led to us at Leonard in all its sadness. This film based on a true story lives not only from the very emotional moments of awakening and the hopeful, but short wax of these poor people, but also from his clear message: sometimes life is short, so we are careful with him. The Duo Williams and De Niro make from the already very emotional history through their brilliant game a sensitive film, which will remain in memory.Motional moments of awakening and the hopeful but short wax of these poor people, but also from his clear message: Sometimes life is short, so we go carefully with him. The Duo Williams and De Niro make from the already very emotional history through their brilliant game a sensitive film that will remain in memory.

product_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes - Triple Play (Blu-ray + DVD + Digital Copy) [Region Free]
review_headline: Much better than the last one.
review_body: This is an excellent movie, much better than the last Planet of the Apes film.  I only have one gripe to do with the packaging. I dimmed the lights, opened the box, saw a sheet of paper at one side and the disk at the other, so I popped the disk in the machine and watched it, only to discover at the end of the film that I'd watched the DVD version instead of the blu-ray disk. The blu-ray disk was hidden behind the sheet of paper explaining the digital copy. I've always hated paying for triple packs when I just want blu-ray but now I'm actually thinking of reverting back to DVDs. If there's a chance of watching the DVD by accident then I might as well buy the DVD in the first place and save myself some money.  On the plus side, it goes to show how good a movie this is if I didn't even realise I was watching a poorer quality DVD version rather than blu-ray.

On the plus side, it goes to show how good a movie this is if I didn't even realise I was watching a poorer quality DVD version rather than blu-ray.

review_headline: Good game shame about the in app purchases required!!!!
review_body: I really enjoy this game as it has a twist on hidden object game by alternating the clue style & would give it 5 stars had it not be one of those games that lures you in then just as you get into it BAM.to progress you need to buy crystals &  coins. You can play the game without buying but it is slow progress as you have to wait for your coins to replenish plus some levels require high amount of crystals that are not easy to come by so these will need to be brought to carry on. The scenes get harder as you go on & some items are VERY difficult to find so be prepared to use some hints as each scene has a time limit. Have fun :-)

review_body: Zyklische Einspielungen der Sinfonien Schuberts sind selten zu finden. Zumeist finden nur die \"Unvollendete\" und die Große C-Dur Beachtung. Dabei sind die frühen Sinfonien Schuberts keineswegs nur belanglose Jugendwerke, bilden sie doch Einflüsse auf Berlioz, Bruckner und Dvorak. Liszt, der großen Anteil an der posthumen Würdigung des Werkes Schuberts besitzt, beschrieb ihn als den \"poetischsten Musiker, der je gelebt hat\" Diese Schnittstelle unterschiedlicher Stile ist es auch, die in diesen Live-Aufnahmen aus dem Münchner Herkulessaal als zentrales Schlüsselelement von Maazel herausgearbeitet wird. Die Akustik des Saals bildet einen warmen, angenehmen resonanten Klang, bei dem das Orchester anscheinend kammermusikalische Größe hat, nur um in den dramatischeren Passagen sich in voller Pracht zu zeigen. Insbesondere die Holzbläserstimmen erhalten in den Menuettos der ersten fünf Sinfonien so gut hörbare Präsenz und zeigen die Freude welche die Musiker bei der Aufführung gehabt haben müssen. Eine entspannte Heiterkeit, die in historisch informierten Einspielungen häufig einer Hetzjagd geopfert wird. Gekrönt wird dies in den letzten beiden Sinfonien, wo die tatsächliche Dramatik der Werke nochmals unterstrichen wird, ohne die innere Durchhörbarkeit zu verlieren. Im Vergleich zur Aufnahme von Günter Wand und den Berliner Philharmonikern sieht man hier, merkt man die Fähigkeiten Maazels durch subtile Ritardandos größtmögliche Wirkung zu erzielen. Häufig wird ihm Routiniertheit oder Leblosigkeit im Umgang mit Musik in der Wirkung seiner Studioaufnahmen nachgesagt. Diese Live-Dokumente widerlegen diese Annahme dank eines glänzend disponierten Sinfonieorchesters des Bayerischen Rundfunks aufs wunderbarste. Sehr empfehlenswert auch für Einsteiger.
translated_review: Cyclic recordings of Symphonies Schuberts are rare to find. Mostly only find the "unfinished \" and the big C major attention. The early Symphonies are by no means only trivial youth plants, they make influences on Berlioz, Bruckner and Dvorak. Liszt, the great proportion of the posthumous appreciation of the work of Schubert, described him as the "poetic musician who has ever lived \" This interface of different styles is also that in these live recordings from the Munich Herculessaal as a central key element worked out of Maazel. The acoustic of the hall forms a warm, pleasant resonant sound in which the orchestra apparently has a chamber music size, only to show in the more dramatic passages in full splendor. In particular, the wooden blower voices receive so well audible presence in the menuettos of the first five symphonies and show the joy which the musicians had to have at the performance. A relaxed cheerfulness that is often sacrificed in historically informed recordings of a hunt. This is crowned in the last two symphonies, where the actual drama of the works is underlined again without losing the internal impossibility. Compared to the inclusion of Günter Wall and the Berliner Philharmoniker you can see here, you realize the skills Maazels by subtle Ritardando's greatest possible effect. Often, carelessness or lifelessness in dealing with music is said to him in the impact of his studio recordings. These live documents refute this assumption, thanks to a glossy disposed symphony orchestra of Bayerischer Rundfunk. Highly recommended also for beginners.

product_title: Das Parfum - Die Geschichte eines Mörders (Premium Edition) [2 DVDs]
review_headline: Starke Umsetzung eines wirklich überragenden Buches
review_body: Als ich vor Jahren dieses Buch gelesen habe (ein Klassiker der deutschen Literatur), habe ich mir gewünscht das dieses Buch mal verfilmt wird. Tom Twyker machte dies nun wahr und es ist ihm durchaus gelungen.    Habe diesen Film in der Ớriginalfassung gesehen (im Kino) und war wirjklich beeindruckt. Ein Buch in dem es zum Gerüche geht zu verfilmen grenzt an eine Meisterleistung und ist verdammt schwer auf die Leinwand zu bringen, aber durch geschickte Visualität, grandiose Schauspieler und bleibende Bilder istz es dem Regisseur gelungen, den Zuschauern ein Bild des Paris und des J.B. Grenouille zu vermitteln, welches man nicht so schnell vergisst.    Sehr beeindruckendfand ich die Szene, als der Grrenouille auf ddem Pariser (Fisch)markt zwischen all diesen Abfällen geboren wird und dann von seiner Mutter einfach liegen gelassen wird. Das war schon etwas, was unter die Haut geht. Auch die Szenen in den Ben Wishaw den \"Duft der Frauen\" konserviert sind wirklich hervorragend in Szene gesetzt. Teilweise waren die Szenen nicht unbedingt etwas für schwache Nerven, aber wie hätte man es besser darstellen können.    5 Sterne bekommt der Film nicht, weil dazu noch mehr gehört, als nur diese Umsetzung. Mir hat irgendiwe etwas gefehlt (noch mehr Flair, bessere musikalische Unterlegungen), dann hätte er die vollen Sterne bekommen, aber trotz allem ist dieser Film sicher ein Highlight derr Filmgeschichte und mehr als nur sehenswert.    Ich hoffe mal, das die DVD (hoffentlich mit reichlich Bonusmaterial) diese Niveau noch toppen kann.

Have seen this movie in the ớriginal version (in the cinema) and was pierced. A book in which it goes to smells to a masterpiece adjacent to a masterpiece and is damn hard to bring on the canvas, but by skilful visuality, grandiose actors and lasting pictures it suddenly succeeded in the director, the viewers have a picture of Paris and J.B. Grenouille to convey, which you do not forget so fast. I was very impressive, I found the scene when the Grrenouille is born on DDEM Parisian (fish) market between all these waste and then was easy to lie by his mother. That was something that goes under the skin. The scenes in the Ben Wishaw also preserved the \ "fragrance of women \" are really greatly staged. Partly the scenes were not necessarily something for a weak nerves, but how could you be able to portray it better. 5 stars does not get the movie because even more than just this implementation. I missed something like that (even more flair, better musical instructions), then he would have got the full stars, but despite everything, this film is certainly a highlight of the film history and more than worth seeing. I hope that the DVD (hopefully with plenty of bonus material) can still top this level.

product_title: A Feast for Crows (A Song of Ice and Fire, Book 4)
review_headline: Insomnia-inflicting, nail-bitingly intense and breathtakingly epic this truly is a work of pure genius!
review_body: George RR Martin has to be one of the greatest fantasy writers of all-time and whose work, in my opinion, is as close to a modern-day version of JRR Tolkien. The depth that the author delves into is quite extraordinary with the extensive world-building and cleverly crafted, intricately detailed plot as something to admire. The tale that began in `Game of thrones' continues in book 4: A song of ice and fire, with the war still raging in the seven kingdoms and a deep-rooted conflict reaching its pinnacle. This absorbing, exciting read will have you hooked within the first few pages, loosing yourself within a mammoth tale of bittersweet revenge, heated rage and ambition. A master of epic fantasy George RR Martin has produced something so remarkably stunning, of such breathtaking scope, that you will be hard pressed to find something to equal `A song of ice and fire'.  Crows will fight over a dead man's flesh, And kill each other for his eyes.  Bloodthirsty, treacherous and cunning, the Lannisters are in power on the Iron throne in the name of the boy-King Tommen. The war in the seven kingdoms has burned itself out, but in its bitter aftermath new conflicts spark to life. The Martells of Dorne and the Starks of Winterfell seek vengeance for their dead. Euron Crow's eye, as black as a pirate ever raised a sail, returns from the smoking ruins of Valyria to claim the Iron Isles. From the icy north, where others threaten the Wall, apprentice Maester Samwell Tarly brings a mysterious babe in arms to the Citadel.  Against a backdrop of incest and fratricide, alchemy and murder, victory will go to the men and women possessed of the coldest steel and the coldest hearts.  This slab of a book (854 pages long + appendices) is certainly something to `stick your teeth into' and which will have you glued to the page for hours on end, days and months. As an avid reader of the fantasy genre this is a series that by far outshines many others with its atmospheric, starkly realistic picture that the author captures; purely graphic, bloodthirsty and gritty. Dramatic battle scenes that shake you to the core, heated divergence amidst rulers and great leaders and intense passion - this is an astonishing tale! Never have I been rendered speechless by an author whose accomplished writing ability, and astonishing creative visionary is truly noteworthy for this is a book that gives you Goosebumps.  This is a book that had me lost within a trance for several months, with the hairs on the back of my arms standing on end and with chills running down my spine.just an epic masterpiece of sheer brilliance!s with its atmospheric, starkly realistic picture that the author captures; purely graphic, bloodthirsty and gritty. Dramatic battle scenes that shake you to the core, heated divergence amidst rulers and great leaders and intense passion - this is an astonishing tale! Never have I been rendered speechless by an author whose accomplished writing ability, and astonishing creative visionary is truly noteworthy for this is a book that gives you Goosebumps.  This is a book that had me lost within a trance for several months, with the hairs on the back of my arms standing on end and with chills running down my spine.just an epic masterpiece of sheer brilliance!

review_body: Nachdem der erste Teil DER Kracher war, haben wir uns nun auch den zweiten Teil gekauft.  Die Handlung ist mehr oder weniger eine Wiederholung des ersten Teils, nur dieses Mal in Bangkok.  Die Story ist ebenso abgedreht, allerdings sind die Gags dieses Mal deutlich schwächer und wirken teils wie mit der Brechstange. Die echten Lacher kommen denn auch in deutlich größeren Abständen. Häufig wird einfach nur versucht, mit Gags unterhalb der Gürtellinie zu punkten - was meistens misslingt.  Insgesamt kann man sich den Film anschauen, wenn ansonsten nur das Musikantenstadl oder DSDS im Fernsehen kommen. Ein Muss ist der Film aber nicht.

product_title: The Paradox of Choice: Why More Is Less (P.S.)
review_body: Hervorragendes Buch das einem erklärt weshalb es sich lohnt sich auf das Wesentliche zu beschränken und mehr nicht mehr sondern eigentlich weniger bedeutet, da man sich an dem mehr gar nicht erfreuen kann. Das Buch liest sich sehr einfach. Anhand von vielen Beispielen und Studien erläutert der Autor wie sich das Individium oder Gruppen verhalten, wenn es gilt eine Auswahl zu treffen. In vielen dieser Beispiele wird sich der Leser wieder erkennen.    Den einzigen Kritikpunkt den ich habe, ist die Länge des Buches. Hier wäre weniger vielleicht mehr gewesen. Trotzdem 5 Sterne da es so gut geschrieben ist, dass es sich wie ein Roman liest.
translated_review: Excellent book that explains why it is worth to limit itself to the essentials and more not more but actually less means that it can not be delighted.The book reads very easily.On the basis of many examples and studies, the author explains how the individual or groups behave if there is a selection to make.In many of these examples, the reader will recognize itself again.The only criticism I have is the length of the book.Here, less may have been more.Nevertheless, 5 stars as it is so well written that it reads like a novel.

review_body: Back before Charlie Sheen had made it to Vietnam in his own film and before Martin Sheen became President, there was this film, Apocalypse Now. The history of the film is as fascinating as the characters who comprise the film (both on and off screen), as is also true of the subject matter -- the controversial and star-crossed venture of America into the dense jungles of southeast Asia.  While the director, Francis Ford Coppola, will be remembered for his involvement in many major films (such as American Grafitti, the Godfather series), this film will most likely be the most enduring not only of his works, but also of American war films. There is a darkness, an eerie mystery that is woven throughout the tale of Captain Willard (Sheen) going into the jungle on a mission he can't tell anyone about, and as we come to learn, this is not merely because he is sworn to secrecy, but discovers that he himself doesn't know what is happening much of the time. Even as confused and mysterious as the war seemed to the American people (and, as it turns out, the American government), it was no more clear to the soldiers in-country, many of whom developed their own sense of loyalty, community and hierarchies of significance quite independent of the leadership's intentions or the overall war strategies. Colonel Kurtz has taken off in deep inland areas, and set himself up as a tribal leader and godlike figure for the indigenous peoples, over and against the invaders, who were more the Americans than anyone else. Willard task was to eliminate Kurtz, but falls under the spell of both the jungle and Kurtz's megalomanical personality. The crew accompanying Willard gets killled off one by one during the journey and at the camp, until it becomes an epic battle of the spirit, as confused and as ferocious as the Vietnam war itself. This is a film full of stars in minor roles -- Harrison Ford, Robert Duvall (whose line 'I love the smell of napalm in the morning' is perhaps the quintessential quotable-quote of the film), Dennis Hopper, Laurence Fishburn -- even an uncredited R. Lee Ermey ('Full Metal Jacket') appears, as does a cameo by Coppola himself. Of course, virtually every role in the film is minor save two, that of Sheen (as Captain Williard) and Marlon Brando (as the prey, or is it hunter, Colonel Kurtz).  The Redux version is nearly an hour longer than the 'original' cut, already a long film at 2 1/2 hours. This one comes in a hour longer, with footage that fills the gaps in the plot of the original, including an important section at a country villa that the original colonials, the French, never gave up in the generla retreat from the country.  The effects are dark and foreboding, spectacular without being overdone or unrealistic. From the relentless trip up river to the blowing of the bridge and the air strikes, everything seems both real and unreal, as is often reported about actual combat from experienced soldiers. That the film won best Oscars for cinematography and sound attests to the quality here, which the DVD experience enhances. The film was also nominated for best film, best supporting actor (Duvall), and director (among other categories), and won numerous awards around the world in other venues.  The inspiration from Joseph Conrad's 'Heart of Darkness' is clear -- the war's absurdity has driven everyone mad -- the French villa's inhabitants demonstrate a gentle and sad insanity, Kurtz exhibits the rebellious dictatorial insanity, Willard the establishment insanity, and all around are mad in their own rights. This is a journey into hell, but one discovers that hell was also the starting point. There is no redemption here, and the ending, while more clear and explicit in this Redux version, still leaves the viewer wanting explanations that, much like those for the war itself, simply do not exist. The horsemen of the apocalypse, bringing disease and war and death, virtually gallop through this film.  To watch this film is not to understand the war, but perhaps one will appreciate it better. Every war is an apocalypse; every war represents the end to peace and hope. Yet there is a world on the other side for those who will survive -- the question becomes, who wants to survive to remember?

review_body:
Ich habe Slipknot zwar bisher nie live gesehen aber diese Doppel-CD
macht auch nicht gerade lust auf mehr.
Die Songauswahl ist echt gut gerade weil sie viel von ihrem letzten Album Volume 3. spielen. Dazwischen reihen sich die beliebtesten Songs der Vorgänger Alben ein.
Aber ein gutes Konzert braucht eben mehr wie eine gute Setlist gerade wenn es sich um einen so abgefeierten Act handelt.
Die Band spielt gut und auch recht tight.
Der erste große Knackpunkt das Übermaß an Bass bringt zwar ordentlich Druck allerdings geht das auf die Kosten der Soundtransparenz. Viele Arrangements verschwimmen so im Soundwall
der Band.
Richtig mies wird es allerdings bei den Vocals zum einen leiden die cleanen Passagen gehörig, Die Hooklines von Duality und Before i forget gehen fast komplett flöten der Gesang klingt angestrengt und Dumpf (Vieleicht sollte mann einfach mal die Masken beim Singen abnehmen). Auch die Shouts sind dermaßen dünn und schwach das es einfach nicht mehr schön ist.

I've never seen Slipknot live, but this double CD
does not just want more.
The song selection is really good just because you play a lot from your last album Volume 3. Play. In between, the most popular songs of its predecessor albums rows. But a good concert just needs more like a good setlist just when it is such a broken ACT.
The band plays well and right tight.
The first big sticking point The excess of bass brings neat pressure, however, this is due to the cost of sound transparency. Many arrangements blur so in the soundwall of the band.
Ready Mies it will suffer from the vocals to suffer the Clean's passages belonging to the Hookclines of Duality and Before I Forget almost completely flutes of the singing sounds strained and dull ( Maybe man should simply remove the masks while singing). Even the shous are so thin and weak that it just is not beautiful anymore.

product_title: Seiko - SYMC07K1 - Montre Femme - Automatique - Analogique - Bracelet Acier Inoxydable Argent
review_body: La montre est arrivée comme prévu, bien emballée, bien protégée. Pas de problème pour la mise en route, d'allure assez sympa (enfin je trouve, c'est un cadeau pour ma femme). Attention, si la montre n'est pas portée plus de 24 heures, elle aurait tendance à s'arrêter. J'ai eu une montre sur le même principe et elle tenait bien 48 heures. Le bouton du remontoir est assez dur, à l'utiliser on a peur de forcer et qu'il reste dans les mains.
translated_review: The watch has arrived as expected, well packaged, well protected.No problem for startup, look quite nice (finally I find, it's a gift for my wife).Attention, if the watch is not worn more than 24 hours, it would tend to stop.I had a watch on the same principle and she was holding 48 hours.The winder button is hard enough, using it is afraid of forcing and staying in the hands.

review_headline: Schöne Wiederveröffentlichung, allerdings eine Maxi gekürzt!
review_body: Auch ich habe mich gefreut das Tina's bestes Album mit viel Bonus zum Jubiliäum noch mal veröffentlicht wird. Das dies Hammeralbum ist bedarf keiner besonderen Erwähnung und wurde hier ja auch genug erwähnt. An der Klangqualität und der Titelauswahl gibt's für mich nichts zu meckern, besser kann man es nicht machen. Für mich war vor allem die 2. Scheibe interessant weil da alle vom Album erschienen 12'' Versionen zu finden sind. Da ist mir leider aufgefallen das der 12" (bzw. Extended) Remix von "Better Be Good To Me" um knapp 40 Sekunden gekürzt (oder früher ausgeblended) wurde. Auf dieser Collection 7:04 min aber im Original halt 7:40 min lang. Warum macht man sowas? Für den Sammler ist es ärgerlich und deshalb setze ich meine Bewertung für dieses (sonst gute) Release um einen Stern herunter - gekürzte Titel dürfen nicht sein. Zum Glück besitze ich noch den australischen Sampler "Private Dance Mixes", da ist sie vollständig.
translated_review: Also I was pleased to publish the Tina's best album with a lot of bonus for the jubilee again.This Hammer album is needed no special mention and was mentioned here enough.At the sound quality and the title selection, there's nothing to complain for me, you can not do it better.For me, especially the 2nd disc was interesting because all of the album appeared 12 '' versions to be found.Unfortunately, I noticed that of the 12 "(or extended) remix of" Better Be Good to me "was shortened by just under 40 seconds (or formed earlier). On this collection 7:04 min but in the original stop 7:40 minlong. Why do you make something? For the collector, it is annoying and therefore I set my rating for this (otherwise good) release for a star - shortened title must not be. Luckily, I still own the Australian sampler "Private Dance Mixes", because it is complete.

product_title: Team America: World Police [Special Collector's Edition]
review_body: Team America ist die Sondereinsatztruppe gegen Terrorismus und weltweit im Einsatz. Dass beim Bombardieren der freiheitshassenden Bastarde mal ein Kulturschatz wie die Pyramiden oder ein nationales Symbol wie der Eiffelturm zerstört wird geht als minimaler Kollateralschaden durch. Die Welt muss Amerika doch dankbar für das Eingreifen sein, und wer kann schon einen Preis festsetzen für das Erhalten der Westlichen Werte?  Dieser Film bietet für jeden etwas, beide Seiten (Kriegsgegner und -befürworter) kriegen ihr Fett weg. Herrlich die Darstellungen der Hollywood Elite in ihrem Bestreben um eine friedliche Lösung, die Kurzsichtigkeit der Terrorbekämpfung und die politisch höchst inkorrekte Überzeichnung aller involvierten. Die Terroristen werden übrigens vom bösen Kim Jong Il dirigiert. Heimat der Fanatisten ist Durkadurkistan, und ihr Vokabular besteht hauptsächlich aus \"Durka! Durka! Mohhamed Dschihad\". Der Unterhaltungswert steigt mit dem Allgemeinwissen des Sehers, so hilft es ungemein zu wissen dass es ein Musical namens Rent gibt, und worum es darin geht. Referenzen an Star Wars dürfte ja wohl jeder kapieren :-) Auch die Songs haben viel zu bieten wenn man genau zuhört, mein persönlicher Favorit ist 'Pearl Harbor'.  Die Pruduktion ist sehr hochkarätig, die Puppen sind eine gelungene Weiterentwicklung von Gerry Anderson's Super-Marionation, die Sets unglaublich detailverliebt (was es umso schlimmer macht dass wir uns beim Remake von Thunderbirde mit einem zweitklassigen Realfilm zufrieden geben mussten). Wer South Park mag, Fäkalhumorresistent ist und überdrehte Satire liebt, der ist mit dem Team America gut bedient. Fuck Yeah!
translated_review: Team America is the special deployment force against terrorism and in use worldwide. That when bombing the freedom-based bastards a cultural treasure such as the pyramids or a national symbol like the Eiffel Tower is destroyed as a minimal collateral damage. The world must be grateful to America for intervention, and who can already set a price for obtaining the western values? This movie offers something for everyone, both sides (war opponents and advocates) get their fat away. The representations of the Hollywood elite in their endeavor to a peaceful solution, the short-sightedness of terrorist control and the politically highly incorrect transcription of all involved. Incidentally, the terrorists are conducted by the evil Kim Jong Il. Home of the fanatists is Durkadurkistan, and her vocabulary consists mainly \ "Durka! Durka! Mohhamed Jihad \". The entertainment value increases with the general knowledge of the seher, so it helps to know that there is a musical named Rent, and what it's all about. References to Star Wars should probably get everyone :-) The songs have a lot to offer if you listen exactly, my personal favorite is 'Pearl Harbor'. The pruduction is very high-class, the dolls are a successful further development of Gerry Anderson's Super-Marionation, the sets incredibly detailed in detail (which makes it all the worse that we had to satisfy ourselves with a second-rate real film with a second-rate real film). Who likes South Park, Fäkalhumorresistent and loves overturned satire, who is well served with the Team America. Fuck Yeah!

product_title: How I Met Your Mother - Season 7 [3 DVDs]
review_body: Ich habe die Staffel meinem Freund zu Weihnachten geschenkt (natürlich auch mit etwas eigenem Interesse :-) ), weil er so ein Fan von HIMYM ist. Wir haben auch die erstbeste Gelegenheit ergriffen und die DVD in den Player geschmissen und uns angefangen eine Folge nach der anderen reinzuziehen. Und es war einfach toll! Barney mit dieser ulkigen Entenkrawatte! Einfach nur zum Schreien komisch! Lillys Schwangerschaft ist auch echt cool! Besonders die Folge wo ihre Zurechnungsfähigkeit fragwürdig ist! Jede Folge ist einfach auf ihre eigen Art und Weis urkomisch, aber auch manchmal ernst, wie als Robin die schlechte Nachricht erhält (welche will ich nicht so einfach verraten, wär ja sonst langweilig). In dieser neuen Staffel ist das Gleichgewicht zwischen Ernst und Lustig wieder sehr ausgewogen und ich kann sie allen Fans nur empfehlen! Letzenendes geht es aber doch nur um die eine entscheidende Frage: WER IST DIE FRAU MIT DEM GELBEN REGENSCHIRM? Werden wir es endlich hier erfahren oder nicht! Wer weiß :-)
translated_review: I gave the season to my friend for Christmas (of course also with something own interest :-)) because he is such a fan of Himym. We also seized the first opportunity and the DVD will be thrown into the player and starting to pull us one sequence after the other. And it was just great! Barney with this ulcious duck tie! Just to scream funny! Lilly's pregnancy is really cool! Especially the result where your ability is questionable! Each episode is simply on their own kind and weis urkomically, but sometimes serious, as Robin receives the bad news (which I do not want to betray that simply, would otherwise be boring). In this new season, the balance between seriousness and funny is very balanced again and I can only recommend it to all fans! But the ends are only about the a crucial question: who is the woman with the yellow umbrella? We will finally know it here or not! Who knows :-)

review_body: Une fois encore BECK prouve qu'il est un touche à tout, mais pas n'importe lequel. Car tout ce qu'il touche se transforme en mélodie implacable, un album très intimiste, parfois sombre qui ne véhicule que du bonheur.Certainement l'album le plus réussi après ODELAY et MUTATION.Plus proche de ce dernier, il recèle  quelques perles. Comment ne pas frissonner sur des morceaux comme Lost cause, All in your mind, ou paper Tiger (qui n'est pas sans rappeler GAINSBOURG façon l'homme à tête de chou).Mais n'est pas dans l'inspiration des plus grands que notre ami BECK excèle le plus. mille fois Merci à BECK pour ce bonheur
translated_review: Once again Beck proves that it is a touch of everything, but not any one.Because all that it touches is transformed into a relentless melody, a very intimate album, sometimes dark that does only have happiness.Certainement the most successful album after Odelay and Mutation.Presse close to the latter, he contains some pearls.How not to shiver on pieces like Lost Cause, All in your Mind, or Paper Tiger (who is not without reminding Gainsbourg way the man head with cabbage). But is not in the inspiration of the greatestthat our friend Beck excels the most.a thousand times thank you to Beck for this happiness

review_body: j'ai eu l'occasion de voir ce film au cinéma (absurde séance de Nantes)et comme j'ai adoré, j'ai commandé ce blu-ray sur amazon, je ne vais pas m'étaler sur le blu-ray en lui même qui est assez décevant, l'image est plutôt moyenne (même horrible lors de la première scène), en tout cas elle n'est pas mieux que le DVD. mais je vais plutôt me concentrer sur le film qui est une vraie perle du cinéma gore et excentrique japonais, je n'avais rien de vu de tel depuis Tetsuo ou Ichi the killer! On y retrouve une police totalitaire et expéditive, des mutants tous aussi originaux les uns que les autres, une chasseuse de mutants qui parle peu mais qui charcute sévère le sabre à la main! Et une quantité démesurée d'hémoglobine! le film est plutôt long : 1h49 mais ça passe très vite, le film est bien monté malgré un budget moyen, les scènes d'actions nerveuses a souhait et les nombreuses \"fausses pubs\" qui interviennent tout le long sont jubilatoires malgré leur humour trash et sans retenue. Les effets spéciaux à l'ancienne pour la plupart et couplés par moment à de l'image de synthèse sont fabuleux a mon goût, bourrés d'idées incroyables et par moment absurde au possible! bref un film qui ne passe pas inaperçu a conseiller aux amateurs! je précise que dans le même genre et sortis précédemment, on trouve the machine girl et meatball machine, sinon plus récemment est sorti vampire girl VS frankenstein girl : une autre bijou du même réalisateur
translated_review: I had the opportunity to see this movie at the cinema (absurd session of Nantes) and as I loved, I ordered this Blu-ray on Amazon, I will not go to the Blu-ray in Itself which is quite disappointing, the image is rather average (even horrible during the first scene), in any case it is not better than the DVD. But I'm going to focus on the movie which is a real pearl of Japanese Gore and eccentric cinema, I had nothing seen from such from Tetsuo or Ichi the Killer! There is a totalitarian and expeditious font, mutants all as original as the others, a mutant hunter who speaks little but who is severely charging the sword by hand! And a disproportionate amount of hemoglobin! The movie is rather long: 1h49 But it goes very fast, the film is well mounted despite a medium budget, the scenes of nervous actions wish and the many \ "false pubs \" who intervene all along are jubilant despite their humor Trash and without restraint. The special adverse effects for the most part and coupled at times at the synthesis image are fabulous for my taste, stuffed with incredible ideas and at an absurd moment as possible! In short, a movie that does not go unnoticed to advise lovers! I specify that in the same kind and went out earlier, we find the machine girl and meatball machine, if not more recently is released vampire girl vs frankenstein girl: another jewel of the same director

review_headline: Eine große Warnung vor einem ambitionierten und leider gescheiterten Film
review_body: Manchmal ist es wirklich traurig eine schlechte Rezension zu einem heiß erwarteten, im Kino verpaßten Filmereignis schreiben zu müssen. Das diese Großproduktion auf jeden Fall nur für Musical- Freunde ist, sei noch einmal ganz deutlich hervorgehoben.  Insofern ist hier schon einmal die deutliche Warnung: Fast kaum eine Textzeile des Films ist gesprochen, wir haben hier fast schon kein Musical mehr sondern eine durchgängige Ớper.  Jawohl, jeder Ớscar sei es  für das Make- Up, Frisuren oder für die Leistung von Anne Hathaway ist berechtigt.  Sie ist auch eine der wenigen Glanzpunkte in der Inszenierung und muß natürlich schon nach einem Drittel der Laufzeit das Schauspielerensemble verlassen.  Ihr wehmütiger, schmerzvoller Gesangspart ist grandios. Ebenso kann auch Hugh Jackmann überaschend gut stimmlich als Sträfling Valjean überzeugen und dann geht es aber gesanglich unglaublich bergab.  Russell Crowe ist ein überragender Schauspieler, als Sänger brechen ihm eklatant die Höhen und Tiefen weg.  Viele andere mühen sich ebenfalls in ihrem stimmlichen Repertoir ab, was jedoch oft verunglückt ist und dem Zuschauer die Gesichtsmuskulatur zusammenzieht.  Dies ist natürlich für ein durchgängig gesungenes Kinoerlebnis schon einmal eine grosse Belastung.  Dabei begnnt der Film erwartungsvoll heroisch und überwältigend.  Die Sträflinge, die das gestrandete Schiff in den Hafen ziehen ist ein bombastisches Bild und verspricht einen großen, dramatischen Kinoabend.  Leider weit gefehlt, denn \"Les Miserables\" ist eine so zähe, schwer erträgliche Schlaftablette geworden, man hat Mühe sie durch zu stehen, selbst als Musicalfreund.  Hier wurde aus der großen Tragik der Story fast kaum Potential herausgezogen, der Fim trotz prächtiger Bilder so ermüdend und platt inszeniert, daß ich Ihnen, lieber Interessent nachhaltig empfehle, ihn sich vielleicht erst einmal als Leih-DVD zu besorgen, um dannüber einen späteren Kauf zu entscheiden.  Der Aufmarsch des Volkes, das gänsehauterregende \"Lied von den Zornigen\", das bewegende Ende bleiben leider die wenigen Höhepunkte.  Ich hatte vor gut 20 Jahren das Glück Schönbergs \"Les Miserables\" sowie auch Webbers  \"Phantom der Ớper\", \"Jesus Christ Superstar\",\"Evita\", \"Miss Saigon (vielleicht das bewegendste) und \"Sunset Boulevard\" (das ungewöhnlich, exzentrischste) in London zu sehen.  Ein großes, phantastisches Erlebnis.  \"Les Miserables\" ist auch live als Musical weit hinter den anderen anzusiedeln, ist aber trotzdem durch das unmittelbare Erleben ein emotionaler Rausch.  Dies fällt natürlich in der Kinoverfimung weg und so werden die trockene und zähe Storyführung um so ersichtlicher.  Trotz allem Bemühen von Regisseur, von Darstellern, von Ausstattung muß man diagnostizieren: \"Les Miserables\" ist ein unglaublich langweilendes, den Zuschauer nur selten mitreissendes Bombastwerk.  Es könnten die längsten zweieinhalb Stunden werden, die sie je im Kinosessel verbracht haben.  Dabei ist der Ausgangsstoff, der umfangreiche Roman Viktor Hugos einer der grössten Klassiker der Literaturgeschichte.  Die ewige Frage nach Schuld und Sühne, nach dem Ruf nach Freiheit, nach schicksalshaften Verstrickungen und blindem Haß in der Gestalt des Polizeibeamten Javert dargestellt und seiner manischen Jagd auf den ehemaligen Sträfling Valjean ist große bewegende Tragödie.  Sieht man einmal von der Musical- Bearbeitung ab, gibt es unzählige Filmadaptionen dieses Stoffes.  Jean Gabin bietet vielleicht die beste Verkörperung, in einem beeindruckenden Film, auch Gerard Depardieu und Liam Neeson konnten überzeugen, und die Grundzüge der dramatischen Geschichte wurden auch immer gerne in die Moderne verlegt. (beispielsweise \"Endstation Schaffott\" mit Alain Delon).  Stoff genug zu fesselnder Dramatik bietet sich hier also, doch diese wird hier in einer aufwendigen aber unsagbar kraftlosen, stimmlich ebenfalls großenteils verschenkten und des Live- Erlebens beraubten Kinobearbeitung nicht erkennbar.  Ebenfalls bietet der Film keine ausgereifte Kameraführung.  Hier wird zuviel unruhig geschaukelt, gewackelt, gekreiselt um den Film unbeholfen zu der Dramatik zu verhelfen, die ihm inszenatorisch fehlt. Auf technischer Seite gibt es auch ein Manko: Für jeden potenziellen Käufer muß klar sein, daß er des Englischen gut mächtig sein sollte um den Film ohne deutsche Untertitel zu erleben.  Denn das ständige zweieinhalbstündige Mitlesen der Untertitel, lenkt natürlich wiederum von der prächtigen Bildinszenierung und den Kompositionen ab.  Eine harte Geduldsprobe.  Meine Empfehlung: Gerade dieses Musical ist nur etwas für ein Live- Erlebnis. Die Unmittelbarkeit der sinnlich erlebten Bühnenpräsenz kann die blasse Story weitgehend kaschieren. Verschenkter filmischer Kraftaufwand auf ganzer Linie, zähe Ớberflächlichkeit ist jedoch hier zweieinhalb Stunden durch zu stehen. Selbst die \"Phantom der Ớper\" Bearbeitung von Joel Schuhmacher hat deutlich mehr filmisches Potential. \"Les Miserables\" ist ein leider gescheitertes Experiment eine Kunstform,nämlich das Bühnenmusical adäquat in ein anderes Genre, den Kinofilm zu adaptieren.  Sie haben sich bemüht und hatten beste Absichten möchte man den Beteiligten auf den Weg geben. Leihen Sie sich, lieber Interessent den Film erst einmal aus und entscheiden Sie dann. Ich habe ihn mir gleich gekauft, das Geld in den Wind geschossen, weil ich gar nicht in Erwägung zog, daß dieser Film schlecht sein könnte.  Ich war bitter enttäuscht ob dieser schön bebilderten, spannungslosen Luftblase, die so gar nicht bewegen, und beeindrucken kann. Dramatik, Leidenschaft, Begeisterung will auch überzeugend inszeniert werden, und wenn die Rolle Anne Hathaways nicht wäre, wäre der Film sicherlich bald ganz vergessen. Steif und konturlos verläßt er sich auf den sagenhaften Reiz der Bilder und versucht in großer Engstirnigkeit ohne eigene Akzente das Musical in die Form eines Spielfilms eins zu eins zu quetschen. Dies mißlingt, ist nur selten mitreissend, sehr oft unglaubwürdig und nervend. Anne Hathaway gehören die stärksten, emotionalsten Momente.  Sehr schade, daß natürlich ihre zeitlich begrenzte Rolle nun wirklich nicht ein verunglücktes Mammutwerk retten kann.  Sie wollen ein umwerfendes Filmmusical sehen, welches einen wahren wunderschönen und unglaublich beeindruckenden Rauschzustand hervorruft, welches alle Sinne anspricht und meisterhaft die Genres Kino, Musical zusammenführt?  Dann empfehle ich Ihnen \"Moulin Rouge\". Diesen Flm kann ich auch beim -zigsten mal noch genießen und mich in den Zauber, seine magische Faszination entführen lassen. \"Les Miserables\" bleibt ein überambitioniertes, sehr fades, anstrengendes Erlebnis, was man sich getrost ersparen kann.

product_title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
review_headline: One of the best books I have ever read
review_body: If you're anything like me, you've probably never heard about Henrietta Lacks, although you might have heard about HeLa cells. The first line of immortal cells, that have been used to research what causes cancer, and how can we suppress it, developing drugs for herpes, influenza, leukemia and Parkinson's disease. With their help scientists have been able to study sexually transmitted diseases, lactose digestion, human longevity, etc., and today these cells can be found in almost every laboratory in the world.  The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks by Rebecca Skloot covers all of the important research that became possible thanks to the HeLa cells, and just as importantly, it covers the background story of Henrietta Lacks, a poor, black tobacco-farmer who died of cervical cancer in 1951 - never even knowing that the cells had been taken from her, or what they were being used for. It is also the story of a racist, class-divided society where the children of the woman, whose cells made millions and made so much important research possible, cannot themselves afford health insurance or health care. Furthermore it raises vital ethical questions around tissue donation, research and who profits.  Skloot shows the appalling reality behind how many African-Americans were treated in research: ""What do you know about African-Americans and science?" I told him about the Tuskegee syphilis study like I was giving an oral report in history class: It started in the thirties, when U.S. Department of Public Health researches at the Tuskegee Institute decided to study how syphilis killed, from infection to death. They recruited hundreds of African-American men with syphilis, then watched them die slow, painful, and preventable deaths, even after they realized penicillin could cure them. The research subjects didn't ask questions. They were poor and uneducated, and the researchers offered incentives: free physical exams, hot meals, and rides into town on clinic days, plus fifty-dollar burial stipends for their families when the men died. The researchers chose black subjects because they, like many whites at the time, believed black people were a "notoriously syphilis-soaked race." The public didn't learn about the Tuskegee study until the seventies after hundreds of men enrolled in it had already died. The news spread like pox through black communities: doctors were doing research on black people, lying to them, and watching them die. Rumors started circulating that the doctors had actually injected the men with syphilis in order to study them. "What else?" Pattillo grumbled. I told him I'd heard about so-called Mississippi Appendectomies, unnecessary hysterectomies performed on poor black women to stop them from reproducing, and to give young doctors a chance to practice the procedur. I'd also read about the lack of funding for research into sickle-cell anemia, a disease that affected blacks almost exclusively."  She also illuminates how rarely people would questions doctors in the 1950's, especially not if you were African-American: "In early June [1951], Henrietta told her doctors several times that she thought the cancer was spreading, that she could feel it moving through her, but they found nothing wrong with her. "The patient states that she feels fairly well," one doctor wrote in her chart, "however she continues to complain of some vague lower abdominal discomfort.No evidence of recurrence. Return in one month." There's no indication that Henrietta questioned him; like most patients in the 1950's, she deferred to anything her doctors said. This was a time when "benevolent deception" was a common practice - doctors often withheld information from their patients, sometimes not giving them any diagnosis at all. They believed it was best not to confuse or upset patients with frightening terms they might not understand, like cancer. Doctors knew best, and most patients didn't question that. Especially black patients in public wards. This was 1951 in Baltimore, segregation was law, and it was understood that black people didn't question white people's professional judgement. Many black patients were just glad to be getting treatment, since discrimination in hospitals was widespread. There's no way of knowing whether or how Henrietta's treatment would have differed ifs he'd been white. According to Howard Jones, Henrietta got the same care any white patients would have; the biopsy, the radium treatment, and radiation were all standard for the day. But several studies have shown that black patients were treated and hospitalized at later stages of their illnesses than white patients. And once hospitalized, they got fewer pain medications, and had higher mortality rates."  The cells were originally taken from Henrietta without her knowledge or consent, after she died her husband was pressured into giving his permission for an autopsy - and for more cells to be taken. But taking Henrietta's cells without her consent, wasn't the only unethical thing researchers did. HeLa cells were also injected into patients with cancer, as well as healthy people to see what would happen - again without their consent.  While HeLa cells were incredibly useful in research, they also turned out to be much more potent than any researchers could have predicted: "Scientists knew they had to keep their cultures free from bacterial and viral contamination, and they knew it was possible for cells to contaminate one another if they got mixed up in culture. But when it came to HeLa they had no idea what they were up against. It turned out Henrietta's cells could flat through the air on dust particles. They could travel from one culture to the next on unwashed hands or used pipettes; they could ride from lab to lab on researchers' coats and shoes, or through ventilation systems. And they were strong: if just one HeLa cell landed in a culture dish, it took over, consuming all the media and filling all the space. Gartler's findings did not go over well. In the fifteen years since George Gey had first grown HeLa, the number of published articles involving cell culture had more than tripled each year. Scientists had spent millions of dollars conducting research on those cells to study  the behavior of each tissue type, comparing one to another, testing the unique responses of different cell types to specific drugs, chemicals, or environments. If all those cells were in fact HeLa, it would mean that millions of dollars had been wasted, and researchers who'd found that various cells behaved differently in culture could have some explaining to do."  I think the part that really broke my heart, was getting to know Henrietta's children, who for the most part didn't get the chance to really know their mum. Children who for the longest while never even knew that scientists were doing research using their mother's cells - and children who lived in a society where their mother's cells might have made corporations millions of dollars, but they couldn't afford health insurance and health care: "As we walked toward the front door of his building, Zakariyya turned to me. "Them doctors say her cells is so important and did all this and that to help people. But it didn't do no good for her, and it don't do no good for us. If me and my sister need something, we can't even go see a doctor cause we can't afford it. Only people that can get any good from my mother cells - they get rich off our mother and we got nothing." He shook his head. "All those damn people didn't deserve her help as far as I'm concerned."" . ""I know my life could be better and I wish it was," she told me. "When people hear about my mother cells they always say, 'Oh y'all could be rich! Y'all gotta sue JohnHopkin, y'all gotta do this and that.' But I don't want that." She laughed. "Truth be told, I can't get mad at science, because it helped people live, and I'd be a mess without it. I'm a walking drugstore! I can't say nuthin bad about science, but I won't lie, I would like some health insurance so I don't got to pay all that money every month for drugs my mother cells probably helped make."" . "Sonny had a quintuple bypass in 2003, when he was fifty-six years old - the last thing he remembered before falling unconscious under anesthesia was a doctor standing over him saying his mother's cells were one of the most important things that had ever happened to medicine. Sonny woke up more than $125,000 in debt because he didn't have health insurance to cover the surgery."  The bigger questions we are left with, are questions around ethicacy. Do we need to give our consent for our tissues to be used in research? Do we get to decide what kind of research? What about the profits, who gets to share in those? While I think most people would be happy to donate our cells to research, if we can help other people that way, it is a different question if you or your family can't afford health care. Or if corporations are making such large profits from that research, that the results of the research only benefits the few and privileged. "When I tell people the story of Henrietta Lacks and her cells, their first question is usually Wasn't it illegal for doctors to take Henrietta's cells without her knowledge? Don't doctors have to tell you when they use your cells in research? The answer is no - not in 1951, and not in 2009, when this book went to press." . "There are, essentially, two issues to deal with: consent and money. For most people, knowing if and how their tissues are being used in research is a far bigger issue than profiting from them. Yet when this book went to press, storing blood and tissues for research did not legally require informed consent, because the law governing such things doesn't generally apply to tissue research." . ""You can't ignore this issue of who gets the money and what the money is used for," says Clayton. "I'm not sure what to do about it, but I'm pretty sure it's weird to say everybody gets money except the people providing the raw material.""  I highly recommend The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks and frankly think it should be required reading for everyone.ystems. And they were strong: if just one HeLa cell landed in a culture dish, it took over, consuming all the media and filling all the space. Gartler's findings did not go over well. Scientists had spent millions of dollars conducting research on those cells to study  the behavior of each tissue type, comparing one to another, testing the unique responses of different cell types to specific drugs, chemicals, or environments. If all those cells were in fact HeLa, it would mean that millions of dollars had been wasted, and researchers who'd found that various cells behaved differently in culture could have some explaining to do."  I think the part that really broke my heart, was getting to know Henrietta's children, who for the most part didn't get the chance to really know their mum. Children who for the longest while never even knew that scientists were doing research using their mother's cells - and children who lived in a society where their mother's cells might have made corporations millions of dollars, but they couldn't afford health insurance and health care: "As we walked toward the front door of his building, Zakariyya turned to me. "Them doctors say her cells is so important and did all this and that to help people. But it didn't do no good for her, and it don't do no good for us. If me and my sister need something, we can't even go see a doctor cause we can't afford it. Only people that can get any good from my mother cells - they get rich off our mother and we got nothing." He shook his head. "All those damn people didn't deserve her help as far as I'm concerned."" . ""I know my life could be better and I wish it was," she told me. "When people hear about my mother cells they always say, 'Oh y'all could be rich! Y'all gotta sue JohnHopkin, y'all gotta do this and that.' But I don't want that." She laughed. "Truth be told, I can't get mad at science, because it helped people live, and I'd be a mess without it. I'm a walking drugstore! I can't say nuthin bad about science, but I won't lie, I would like some health insurance so I don't got to pay all that money every month for drugs my mother cells probably helped make."" . "Sonny had a quintuple bypass in 2003, when he was fifty-six years old - the last thing he remembered before falling unconscious under anesthesia was a doctor standing over him saying his mother's cells were one of the most important things that had ever happened to medicine. Sonny woke up more than $125,000 in debt because he didn't have health insurance to cover the surgery."  The bigger questions we are left with, are questions around ethicacy. ""You can't ignore this issue of who gets the money and what the money is used for," says Clayton. "I'm not sure what to do about it, but I'm pretty sure it's weird to say everybody gets money except the people providing the raw material."" translated_review: If you're anything like me, you've probably never heard about Henrietta Lacks, although you might have heard about HeLa cells. The first line of immortal cells, that have been used to research what causes cancer, and how can we suppress it, developing drugs for herpes, influenza, leukemia and Parkinson's disease. With their help scientists have been able to study sexually transmitted diseases, lactose digestion, human longevity, etc., and today these cells can be found in almost every laboratory in the world.  The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks by Rebecca Skloot covers all of the important research that became possible thanks to the HeLa cells, and just as importantly, it covers the background story of Henrietta Lacks, a poor, black tobacco-farmer who died of cervical cancer in 1951 - never even knowing that the cells had been taken from her, or what they were being used for. It is also the story of a racist, class-divided society where the children of the woman, whose cells made millions and made so much important research possible, cannot themselves afford health insurance or health care. Furthermore it raises vital ethical questions around tissue donation, research and who profits.  Skloot shows the appalling reality behind how many African-Americans were treated in research: ""What do you know about African-Americans and science?" I told him about the Tuskegee syphilis study like I was giving an oral report in history class: It started in the thirties, when U.S. Department of Public Health researches at the Tuskegee Institute decided to study how syphilis killed, from infection to death. They recruited hundreds of African-American men with syphilis, then watched them die slow, painful, and preventable deaths, even after they realized penicillin could cure them. The research subjects didn't ask questions. They were poor and uneducated, and the researchers offered incentives: free physical exams, hot meals, and rides into town on clinic days, plus fifty-dollar burial stipends for their families when the men died. The researchers chose black subjects because they, like many whites at the time, believed black people were a "notoriously syphilis-soaked race." The public didn't learn about the Tuskegee study until the seventies after hundreds of men enrolled in it had already died. The news spread like pox through black communities: doctors were doing research on black people, lying to them, and watching them die. Rumors started circulating that the doctors had actually injected the men with syphilis in order to study them. "What else?" Pattillo grumbled. I told him I'd heard about so-called Mississippi Appendectomies, unnecessary hysterectomies performed on poor black women to stop them from reproducing, and to give young doctors a chance to practice the procedur. I'd also read about the lack of funding for research into sickle-cell anemia, a disease that affected blacks almost exclusively."  She also illuminates how rarely people would questions doctors in the 1950's, especially not if you were African-American: "In early June [1951], Henrietta told her doctors several times that she thought the cancer was spreading, that she could feel it moving through her, but they found nothing wrong with her. "The patient states that she feels fairly well," one doctor wrote in her chart, "however she continues to complain of some vague lower abdominal discomfort.No evidence of recurrence. Return in one month." There's no indication that Henrietta questioned him; like most patients in the 1950's, she deferred to anything her doctors said. This was a time when "benevolent deception" was a common practice - doctors often withheld information from their patients, sometimes not giving them any diagnosis at all. They believed it was best not to confuse or upset patients with frightening terms they might not understand, like cancer. Doctors knew best, and most patients didn't question that. Especially black patients in public wards. This was 1951 in Baltimore, segregation was law, and it was understood that black people didn't question white people's professional judgement. Many black patients were just glad to be getting treatment, since discrimination in hospitals was widespread. There's no way of knowing whether or how Henrietta's treatment would have differed ifs he'd been white. According to Howard Jones, Henrietta got the same care any white patients would have; the biopsy, the radium treatment, and radiation were all standard for the day. But several studies have shown that black patients were treated and hospitalized at later stages of their illnesses than white patients. And once hospitalized, they got fewer pain medications, and had higher mortality rates."  The cells were originally taken from Henrietta without her knowledge or consent, after she died her husband was pressured into giving his permission for an autopsy - and for more cells to be taken. But taking Henrietta's cells without her consent, wasn't theonly unethical thing researchers did. HeLa cells were also injected into patients with cancer, as well as healthy people to see what would happen - again without their consent.  While HeLa cells were incredibly useful in research, they also turned out to be much more potent than any researchers could have predicted: "Scientists knew they had to keep their cultures free from bacterial and viral contamination, and they knew it was possible for cells to contaminate one another if they got mixed up in culture. But when it came to HeLa they had no idea what they were up against. It turned out Henrietta's cells could flat through the air on dust particles. They could travel from one culture to the next on unwashed hands or used pipettes; they could ride from lab to lab on researchers' coats and shoes, or through ventilation systems. And they were strong: if just one HeLa cell landed in a culture dish, it took over, consuming all the media and filling all the space. Gartler's findings did not go over well. In the fifteen years since George Gey had first grown HeLa, the number of published articles involving cell culture had more than tripled each year. Scientists had spent millions of dollars conducting research on those cells to study  the behavior of each tissue type, comparing one to another, testing the unique responses of different cell types to specific drugs, chemicals, or environments. If all those cells were in fact HeLa, it would mean that millions of dollars had been wasted, and researchers who'd found that various cells behaved differently in culture could have some explaining to do."  I think the part that really broke my heart, was getting to know Henrietta's children, who for the most part didn't get the chance to really know their mum. Children who for the longest while never even knew that scientists were doing research using their mother's cells - and children who lived in a society where their mother's cells might have made corporations millions of dollars, but they couldn't afford health insurance and health care: "As we walked toward the front door of his building, Zakariyya turned to me. "Them doctors say her cells is so important and did all this and that to help people. But it didn't do no good for her, and it don't do no good for us. If me and my sister need something, we can't even go see a doctor cause we can't afford it. Only people that can get any good from my mother cells - they get rich off our mother and we got nothing." He shook his head. "All those damn people didn't deserve her help as far as I'm concerned."" . ""I know my life could be better and I wish it was," she told me. "When people hear about my mother cells they always say, 'Oh y'all could be rich! Y'all gotta sue JohnHopkin, y'all gotta do this and that.' But I don't want that." She laughed. "Truth be told, I can't get mad at science, because it helped people live, and I'd be a mess without it. I'm a walking drugstore! I can't say nuthin bad about science, but I won't lie, I would like some health insurance so I don't got to pay all that money every month for drugs my mother cells probably helped make."" . "Sonny had a quintuple bypass in 2003, when he was fifty-six years old - the last thing he remembered before falling unconscious under anesthesia was a doctor standing over him saying his mother's cells were one of the most important things that had ever happened to medicine. Sonny woke up more than $125,000 in debt because he didn't have health insurance to cover the surgery."  The bigger questions we are left with, are questions around ethicacy. Do we need to give our consent for our tissues to be used in research? Do we get to decide what kind of research? What about the profits, who gets to share in those? While I think most people would be happy to donate our cells to research, if we can help other people that way, it is a different question if you or your family can't afford health care. Or if corporations are making such large profits from that research, that the results of the research only benefits the few and privileged. "When I tell people the story of Henrietta Lacks and her cells, their first question is usually Wasn't it illegal for doctors to take Henrietta's cells without her knowledge? Don't doctors have to tell you when they use your cells in research? The answer is no - not in 1951, and not in 2009, when this book went to press." . "There are, essentially, two issues to deal with: consent and money. For most people, knowing if and how their tissues are being used in research is a far bigger issue than profiting from them. Yet when this book went to press, storing blood and tissues for research did not legally require informed consent, because the law governing such things doesn't generally apply to tissue research." . ""You can't ignore this issue of who gets the money and what the money is used for," says Clayton. "I'm not sure what to do about it, but I'm pretty sure it's weird to say everybodygets money except the people providing the raw material.""  I highly recommend The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks and frankly think it should be required reading for everyone.ystems. review_body:
\"Lateralus\" war mein Einstieg in die Welt von Tool. Es war ein harter Einstieg, als würde man ins eiskalte Wasser springen. Doch genauso wie sich der menschliche Körper mit der Zeit an die Temperatur des Wasser gewöhnt, gewöhnt man sich an dieses einzigartige Stück Musik.
Zuerst besticht natürlich das geniale Artwork des Albums. Fotos der Band oder Songtexte fehlen im Booklet, stattdessen findet man einige abstrakte Bilder, die auf Folie gedruckt sind. Es tauchen Parallelen zur Musik auf: zunächst findet man die Bilder, die einen systematischen \"Scheibenschnitt\" eines Menschen zeigen, etwas abstoßend, doch später entdeckt man die vielen kleinen Geheimnisse, die in ihnen versteckt sind (Beispielsweise steht das Wort \"God\" auf einer der Folien im Gehirn des Mannes).
Zur Musik: Der Hörer wird mit einem großen achtminütigen Brocken willkommen geheißen. \"The Grudge\" nennt sich dieser Song und zeigt auch sogleich, was einen erwartet. Breaks, Taktwechsel, Refrain Fehlanzeige, harter Gesang, gefühlvoller Gesang, genialer Bass, Wutausbrüche und Songverästelungen, die einen aber meistens wieder auf den Ausgangspfad zurückbringen. Genial, aber sehr komplex und schwer zu erschließen. Aber wenn man \"The Grudge\" einmal verstanden hat, macht es doppelt Spaß. Wenn man genau weiß, wann der nächste Break kommt, was jetzt passiert. Dieser Aspekt macht den Reiz der Tool-werke aus. Mit \"Eon Blue Apocalypse\" folgt ein knapp einminütiges Instrumental, das sofort verzaubert, die erzeugte Spannung aber in Hoffnungslosigkeit ausufern lässt. \"The Patient\" dann beginnt für Toolverhältnisse sehr langsam und ruhig. Doch in Maynards Stimme schwillt wieder diese Bedrohung an. Mit einer Explosion explodiert nach 2 Minuten dann die Bombe, die Verzweiflung nimmt ihren Lauf. Der Song rollt weiter über den Hörer hinweg, gegen Ende laufen sogar zwei verschiedene Gesangslinien übereinander, die dem Hörer einiges an Aufmerksamkeit abverlangen. Danach wird es wieder leiser, aber die mystischen perkussiven Trommeln sind garantiert keine Befreiung. Es geht weiter nach unten. \"Mantra\" verstärkt die Hilflosigkeit des Hörers durch Klänge, die an Walgesänge erinnern. Sehr mystisch. Nach einer Minute setzt dann \"Schism\" ein, das meiner Meinung nach einer der genialsten Songs aller Zeiten ist. Das Bassriff befremdet und der Gesang Maynard James Keenans jagt einem kalte Schauer über den Rücken. Die Worte \"We discover communication\" vefolgen einen. Nach drei Minuten wird es dann leise. Der Schrecken nimmt seinen Lauf. Klänge, von denen man gar nicht wissen will, wo sie herkommen, dringen ans Ohr und später setzt Maynard mit einem unheimlich gefühlvoll-verzweifelten \"From Silence held\" ein. Erneuter Spannungaufbau folgt, harte Gitarrenriffs. Der Song kehrt aufden ursprünglichen Pfad zurück. Doch etwas hat sich verändert. Keine Verzweiflung mehr, eher Wut. \"Oh-oh, gleich kommt der Weltuntergang\" denkt man nur noch und der Double-Bass hämmert auf den Hörer ein. Vorbei. Nach 7 Minuten. Bei \"Parabol\" glaubt man zunächst, auf der sicheren Seite zu sein. Ruhig und gemächlich singt Maynard vor sich hin. Bei dem Hörer erzeugt dies zunächst ein Gefühl des Wohlseins. Denkste. \"Pain is an illusion\" und dann setzen wieder die brachialen progressiven Powergitarren ein. \"Parabola\" heißt die Fortsetzung von \"Parabol\". Der geniale Song wird getragen von unerwarteten Kehrtwendungen, Hoffnungen (die auf dem Album ziemlich selten sind) und dem poetischen Text. \"Dieser Körper hält mich hier unten fest, und er erinnert mich an meine eigene Vergänglichkeit. Schmerz ist nur eine Illusion\" Nach 5 Minuten klingt \"Parabola\" dann langsam aus und lässt den Hörer mit den Fröschen (!) im Wald allein. Im Horrorwald. Wo an jeder Ecke ekelhafte Viecher lauern, die nur eines wollen: Blut. Zecken und Blutegel, die dich aussaugen und kraftlos zurücklassen. Aber wer würde sich einfach so aussaugen lassen? Etwa der kleine, unscheinbare Mann, der dort in der Ecke kauert und vom Schmerz singt? Nein, garantiert nicht. Und so nimmt dieser Mann, namentlich Maynard James Keenan, noch einmal seine letzte Lebenskraft zusammen und lässt einen Schrei fahren, der durch Mark und Bein dringt. \"Ticks & Leeches\" ist der aggressivste Track des Albums und erzeugt mit seiner Dreiteilung eine unheimliche Atmosphäre. \"Lateralus\" nimmt sich dann wieder die Wissenschaft zum Thema und erinnert daher etwas an \"Schism\", immerhin geht es um eine parallele Bewusstseinsebende, um das seitliche, laterale Denken. Der Zwischenteil ist mehr als imposant, hier erinnert Maynards Gesang sehr an \"A Perfect Circle\". Nach 9 Minuten ist \"Lateralus\" dann vorbei und öffnet die Pforte für den experimentellen Progressivteil des Albums. Dieser besteht aus einem 22-minütigen Song, der zwecks der besseren zugänglichkeit in drei Teile unterteilt wurde. \"Disposition\" ist sehr leise und baut langsam Atmosphäre auf. Die perkussiven Klänge und das gegen Ende an Peter Gabriel erinnernde Getrommel wirken sehr dumpf, begeistern aber auf jeden Fall. In \"Reflection\" kommt dann zu den Trommeleinlagen eine orientalische Melodie hinzu, auch der Gesang überzeugt. Das epische Ende dieses 11-minütigen Tracks bereitet den Weg für die instrumentale Donnerwalze \"Triad\". Dieser Song erschlägt den Hörer mit Brachialgitarren, verzerrten Schreien im Hintergrund und orientalischen Melodien. Wenn die Spannung dann unerträglich wird, setzen plötzlich harte Gitarrenriffs ein und \"erlösen\" den Hörer. Überlegter Double-Bass-Einsatz und intelligente Improvisationen, die aber trotzdem sehr durchdacht wirken, lassen beim Hörer das Gefühl eines \"Finale Grande\" aufkommen. Super Ausleitung. Dann Stille. Kommt noch was? Oder wars das nach 73 Minuten etwa schon? Der Hörer stellt sich Fragen und lässt in der zweiminütigen Pause, die nach \"Triad\" folgt, das Album nochmal Revue passieren. dabei sollte er diese Pause eher nutzen, um sich auf das folgende Feuerwerk einzustellen. Leise Töne streicheln das Ohr. Langsam wird es lauter, verkratzt, verzerrt, ein Drumsolo, Maynard mit verzerrter, schmerzerfüllter Stimme. \"Faaip de Oiad\" heißt das Outro und bedeutet soviel wie \"Stimme Gottes\". Für den Hörer ist all dies nur schwer erträglich. Es tut beim ersten Mal richtig weh. Erst nach mehrmaligem Hören dieses schmerzenden Stückes legt sich die Verstöhrtheit. Am besten krallt man sich im Sessel fest und hofft, dass alles schnell vorbei geht. Dann bleibt nach zweieinhalb Minuten dieses Gefühl, an etwas Epischen teilgenommen zu haben, das die meisten nicht verstehen und auch nicht verstehen können. Musik, die schmerzt und den Chrakter des Hörers nicht unverändert lässt. Garantiert nicht. Und sollte sie den Charakter des Hörers doch nicht verändern, so wird er auch keinen Gefallen an der CD finden. Das eine führt unausweichlich zum anderen. Es gibt nur zwei Möglichkeiten: \"Lateralus\" als Meisterwerk hinnehmen und darin aufgehen oder \"Lateralus\" in die Ecke schmeißen und diesen Alptraum so schnell wie möglich vergessen. Dazwischen gibt es nichts.
Für alle, die aud harte emotionale Musik am Rande der verzweiflung stehen und die Musik nicht nur nebenher hören (das geht bei Tool sowieso nicht), kann ich eine klare Empfehlung aussprechen. Das Album braucht sehr viel Zeit. Aber am Ende wird man reich belohnt. Versprochen.
translated_review:
"Lateralus \" was my entry into the world of tool. It was a hard entry as if you were jumping into the ice cold water. But as well as the human body get used to the temperature of the water over time, you get used to this unique piece of music. And first of course, the ingenious artwork of the album impresses. Photos of the band or lyrics are missing in the booklet, instead you will find some abstract images printed on foil. It immerse parallels to music: First of all you will find the pictures that show a systematic \ "disc section" of a person, but later you discover the many little secrets that are hidden in them (for example, the word is "God \ "On one of the slides in the man's brain).
Music: The listener is welcomed with a large eight-minute chunk. "The Grudge \" is called this song and also shows immediately what you expect. Breaks, clock changes, refrain disguise, hard vocals, emotional vocals, ingenious bass, ramparts and song variations, but mostly return to the starting path. Ingenious, but very complex and difficult to tap. But once you understand \ "The Grudge \", it's twice a fun. If you know exactly when the next break comes, what happens now. This aspect makes the stimulus of the tool works. With \ "Eon Blue Apocalypse \" follows a nearly one-minute instrumental, which immediately enchanted, but the generated tension can be distrusted in hopelessness. "The patient \" then starts very slowly and quiet for tool conditions. But in Maynard's voice, this threat will be swelled again. With an explosion, the bomb explodes after 2 minutes, the desperation takes its course.
